parts.text:
```json
{
  "application": "Slurm",
  "details": {
    "job_name": "poi_adam",
    "partition": "amdrome",
    "node": "amd1",
    "nodes": 1,
    "tasks": 2,
    "gpus_per_node": 2,
    "cpus_per_task": 64,
    "gpus_per_task": 1,
    "time": "00:10:00",
    "output": "./stdout_%J",
    "error": "./stderr_%J",
    "modules": [
      "openmpi/4.1.1"
    ],
    "executable": "./wrapper_amd.sh",
    "program": "../build/miniapps/heat3d_mpi/openmp/heat3d_mpi",
    "arguments": [
      "--px 1",
      "--py 1",
      "--pz 2",
      "--nx 512",
      "--ny 512",
      "--nz 256",
      "--nbiter 1000",
      "--freq_diag 0"
    ],
    "environment_variables": {
      "ROCR_VISIBLE_DEVICES": "1,2,3"
    }
  }
}
```

This script uses the Slurm workload manager to run a MPI-based application, likely a heat transfer simulation named "heat3d_mpi". The script defines several Slurm parameters, including job name, partition, node, number of nodes, tasks, GPUs, CPUs, time limit, output file, error file, and modules. The script also sets the `ROCR_VISIBLE_DEVICES` environment variable to specify which GPUs the application should use. 

The script runs the `wrapper_amd.sh` script, which in turn launches the `heat3d_mpi` application with specific parameters like domain size, number of iterations, and diagnostic frequency. The script utilizes OpenMPI for MPI communication.
